entry.title: Understanding the Belgium B2B e-Invoicing Mandate and the Plant Abroad Scenario
entry.content:
Introduction

From January 1, 2026, structured B2B e-invoicing will become mandatory in Belgium for transactions between businesses established in Belgium.
The requirement applies to all domestic B2B supplies of goods and services where both supplier and buyer are VAT-registered and established in Belgium.

SAP supports the Belgian B2B e-Invoicing mandate through SAP Document and Reporting Compliance (SAP DRC), which enables businesses to create and transmit Peppol BIS Billing 3.0 XML invoices in full compliance via the Peppol network.

For foundational details, refer to Peppol Participant Registration for Belgian Companies 

 

The “Plant Abroad” Challenge

Businesses operate through foreign legal entities that maintain fixed establishments in Belgium, often configured in SAP using the Plant Abroad functionality.

Scenario:

  • The head company code is registered in another EU country (e.g., The Netherlands).

  • The company has a Belgian VAT registration and Belgian local address maintained in table T001N.

Transactions are issued under the Belgian VAT number, making them legally in scope of the Belgium e-invoicing mandate.

However, the SAP DRC Belgium B2B e-invoicing solution currently supports only company codes established in Belgium out of the box. This means that for “plant abroad” configurations, extensibility via the SAP DRC standard BAdI .

Workaround: Using the EDOC_ADAPTOR BAdI

Key idea:
Adjust the outbound XML data and replace the seller’s details (VAT ID, GLN, and address) with the Belgian fixed establishment information before submission to Peppol.

Here are the steps:

Master Data Prerequisite

           Verify that in T001N table:

  •  The Belgian VAT number (e.g., BE012345678) is correctly maintained.       
  •  The address number points to the valid local Belgian establishment address (from ADRC).
    BAdI Implementation for EDOC_ADAPTOR--->SET_OUTPUT_DATA.
    1. Read Belgian VAT ID and address number from T001N table.
    2. Assign the following tags in the EDO_UBL_STANDARD_BUSINESS_DOC2  structure:
StandardBusinessDocument\StandardBusinessDocumentHeader\Sender\Identifier​

Sender Endpoint Assignment

StandardBusinessDocument\Invoice\AccountingSupplierParty\Party\EndpointID

          

StandardBusinessDocument\Invoice\AccountingSupplierParty\PartyTaxScheme\CompanyID

 

StandardBusinessDocument\Invoice\AccountingSupplierParty\PartyLegalEntity\CompanyID

 

StandardBusinessDocument\Invoice\AccountingSupplierParty\PostalAddress
StandardBusinessDocument\Invoice\AccountingSupplierParty\PostalAddress\StreetName
StandardBusinessDocument\Invoice\AccountingSupplierParty\PostalAddress\CityName
StandardBusinessDocument\Invoice\AccountingSupplierParty\PostalAddress\PostalZone
StandardBusinessDocument\Invoice\AccountingSupplierParty\PostalAddress\CountrySubentity
StandardBusinessDocument\Invoice\AccountingSupplierParty\PostalAddress\Country\IdentificationCode

 

 

 

Expected Outcome:
  • Successful e-Invoice Submission: 

    The generated XML will now contain the correct Belgian VAT ID and Belgian address information in the relevant Peppol BIS 3.0 fields. The invoice passes both SAP DRC validation and Peppol network checks.

  • Sender Identifier must reflect Belgian Information:

    The Belgian VAT ID or GLN is properly reflected in the Standard Business Document Header of the XML.

  • Correct Endpoint Identification for Peppol Transmission:

    The  <Endpoint> under <AccountingSupplierParty> ensures proper routing within the Peppol network using the Belgian VAT ID or GLN. Also, make sure that the tags <CompanyID> reflect correct Belgian VAT.

  • Accurate Representation of the Fixed Establishment:

    The seller’s postal address represents the Belgian fixed establishment instead of the foreign head office address.

entry.title: Fichier des Écritures Comptables (FEC)
entry.content:
In France we have a legal requirement to submit a file of accounting entries for the closed fiscal year in a dematerialized format (Article L47 A I ) which is effective from 01.01.2014.

Upon receiving request from the tax authorities, a company has 15 days to prepare and submit the FEC file. In case of failing to deliver the FEC file or in the event of non-compliance, companies could face significant penalties

This file consists of entries after inventory operations, excluding centralization entries and excluding entries for balancing expense and revenue accounts. It includes the entries for the recovery of balances from the previous fiscal year and contains, for each entry, all accounting data present in the company's computerized accounting system, with the first eighteen pieces of information required to correspond, in order, to those listed in the following table:

 

 

Further information about the legal requirements can be found here

Article L47 A - Book of Tax Procedures – Légifrance

Article A47 A-1 - Livre des procédures fiscales - Légifrance

How to generate the FEC file from SAP? 

DRC or DART

Document and Reporting Compliance (DRC)

It enables you to create, process, and monitor electronic documents and statutory reports. As a result, your company stays compliant with local legal obligations.

Statutory reporting has been localized for use by businesses with operations in the country/region and it comprises functions designed for laws and business practices relevant in the country/region.

You can generate the audit file for France using the Run Statutory Reports app. This file is referred to as "FEC - Fichier des Écritures Comptables".

Further information can be found here

Supported Compliance Tasks by Country/Region | SAP Help Portal

Audit File (FEC) | SAP Help Portal

Data Retention Tool (DART)

The Data Retention Tool (DART) helps SAP users to meet the legal requirements concerning data retention and data transfer for tax auditing. You can use DART to extract and store data that is relevant to tax from SAP applications at regular intervals. DART extracts the data into sequential files and provides tools that you can use to display and evaluate the stored data.

In general, two steps are required in DART to create machine-readable files for the tax auditor.

The first step in DART involves generating extract files that capture data based on the selected company code and areas like FI, CO, SD, and MM, with customizable restrictions.

In the second step, extract files are transformed into view files according to tax auditor specifications by defining which segments are included and how they are combined.

Further information can be found here

Introduction to the Data Retention Tool (DART) | SAP Help Portal

What are the technical prerequisites for FEC solution by DART?

The recommendation from SAP is to be on the highest version of DART with all the latest notes implemented.

you can check the DART version in the SE11.

You should choose there the "TYPE GROUP": DART1. Then click display

 

The most important technical prerequisites are included in this note

2162977 - DART: Order of implementation of notes for FEC - SAP for Me

Depending on release & support package of the relevant system, some of them should have been delivered by default.

Configuration for DART can be checked in SAP Help Portal

Configuration | SAP Help Portal

DART is often pre-configured for FEC by the installed SAP notes. You mainly need to Configure the Extract File Directories and set directory paths

What is the exact business process?

The prerequisite before running these processes is that your fiscal year is completely closed!

1st step Posting of opening balances France

2nd step Create DART extracts

3rd step Generation of the FEC

Posting of opening balances France

Run Program RFOPENPOSTING_FR with Tcode SE38 or Tcode FAGL_FR_03

This report creates opening entries for balance sheet accounts from the previous year in accordance with the French requirement to submit posting data to the French tax authorities.

Based on the account balances and open items on the key date, FI documents are posted and form the basis of the data extract. These postings represent the balance carryforward but do not generate balances.

For these postings, no subledger documents (customer/vendor/Asset Accounting) are written.

No open items are generated.

The report is available for classic General Ledger Accounting and new General Ledger Accounting.

The documents are specially indicated:

1) The document status is 'O' (balance sheet opening entry).

2) The reference transaction is 'GLYEC' (year-end closing document).

3) The documents are posted in period '0' of the carryforward year.

Documents are generated for each account, customer, and vendor. Information about the customer and vendor is stored in the LIFNR/KUNNR fields as well as in the assignment.

The balances of the respective balance sheet accounts are cleared against "Balance Sheet Account - Opening" on the selection screen.

The posted documents can be reversed with the FI reversal transactions (FB08/F.80).

Compare entries with G/L account Balance Tcode FAGLB03

New list RFOPENPOSTING_FR 

Account balance

Posting List

New open posting in the FEC file

Process Data in DART

Settings for data extraction with Tcode FTWP

Go to FTW1A create the DART extract select FR for the language

You can analyze the extract using the transaction FTWF

Generate FEC File

Start the view 2FR_FI01 with transaction FTWH

 

Go in transaction FTWN you can display and export your generated data

How to test FEC file

The validation program is available on the ministry website

Outil de test des fichiers des écritures comptables (FEC) | Ministère de l’Économie des Finances et de la Souveraineté industrielle et numérique

After installation, run the program. The screen is the same as the one used by the authorities. You should fill the field "Entrer le numéro alpage du dossier" with your number as the file naming example ("111222333"). This is mandatory.

The second field is optional; you can write the name of your company into this.

Also choose the type of your chart of account on the left column (Type de plan comptable) and the type of the revenue category on the right column (Type de revenus). Then you can upload the file to be tested by clicking on the icon "Selectionner un fichier á traiter".

Select the relevant local file. After that your can start the test by clicking on the "Valider" button.

At the end of the test, a summary document is generated in PDF format. It is automatically displayed and saved. The first page of the summary contains general information about this validation process.

The second page shows the mandatory fields required by the law and the fields of the actual FEC file next to it.

Additional notes and comments about the file are displayed on the third page. Generally, these notes have two types: in some cases, these are problems what should be solved in order to get correct file from technical aspect. For example, if there are missing data, it is displayed under the heading „Données absentes”. There are also informational comments, in these cases the file is technically correct. These are displayed under the heading „Observations complémentaires”.

entry.title: Explore SAP Localization With the Global Map of Local Versions
entry.content:
In today’s interconnected world, businesses are growing across borders faster than ever. But with global growth comes local complexity — from tax regulations to payroll rules and legal reporting.

Whether you're a consultant, developer, or business user, navigating country-specific requirements and features can be challenging. SAP simplifies this journey with the global map of local versions. This interactive application is your one-stop destination to explore SAP-provided local versions across the globe.

Ready to explore SAP’s localization capabilities?
Visit sap.com/localization and go global with confidence.

 

What is a local version?

A local version is a set of system functionalities tailored to meet the legal, regulatory, and business requirements of a specific country or region. Think tax reports, payroll rules, or legal reporting formats — all built into SAP solutions to enable compliance and efficiency.

 

Key features of the global map

1. Comprehensive coverage

Explore over 1000 local versions for countries and regions. The global map of local versions simplifies your localization journey by offering a holistic view of SAP’s localization portfolio.

2. Search & filter

Easily find what you need by filtering the interactive map:

  • By Product: Filter by SAP S/4HANA Cloud, SAP SuccessFactors, etc.
  • By Country/Region: Select from a list or use the interactive map.
  • By Deployment Type: Cloud, on-premise
  • By Solution Type: SAP, or Partner solution

The map view provides a visual overview, while the list view offers granular details — ideal for consultants preparing rollout plans or developers assessing localization gaps.

 

3. Stay ahead of regulatory changes

Direct links to SAP’s regulatory change manager help you stay informed about upcoming regulations and how they impact your business. These links are prefiltered for you to continue your localization journey and find prospective regulatory changes.

 

4. Find the right SAP Partner

Need additional localization support? Use the SAP-Qualified Partner-Packaged Solution Finder and search for integrated solutions built, sold, and supported by SAP partners that combine SAP software with industry or line-of-business expertise, services, customizations, or applications.

 

5. Deep dive into SAP business solutions

Want to explore further? Use the direct link to the specific SAP product webpage, access dedicated resources and request a demo to expand your SAP landscape.

 

Realize your global potential with SAP

SAP’s localization capabilities give you the breadth of coverage and depth of expertise to run your business globally — while staying locally compliant.

Visit sap.com/localization and take your business global with confidence.

 

Have you used the global map of local versions for your projects? Share your feedback or tips in the comments below.

entry.title: Підсумки SAP Document and Reporting Compliance Virtual Summit 2025: інсайти та клієнтські кейси
entry.content:

entry.title: SII tip for Spain #5C: SII Adjustments for Canary Islands October 2025 - <BienInversion> and "AJ"
entry.content:
As mentioned in the publication SII tip for Spain #5: SII Adjustments for Canary Islands October 2025, the Canary Islands Tax Agency published the Order of July 10, 2025 modifying Order of 11 October 2018  containing a set of changes in the Canary Islands SII format. In the Annex of this Order, the technical specifications are detailed. In that publication, the new regimes and the AIEM adjustment were mentioned.

In that earlier post, we covered the new regimes and the AIEM adjustment.
In this second part, we focus on two additional changes introduced by the Tax Agency:

Key Enhancements for SAP Customers

  1. Capital Goods Identification
    SAP customers operating in the Canary Islands can now identify incoming invoices related to capital goods (Bienes de inversión).
  2. Adjustment Document Type “AJ”
    For Travel Agencies (REAV) and Used Goods Schema (REBU), it is now possible to record adjustments using a new document type: AJ.

 

 

 

Capital Goods

Similar to SII-Spain, it is possible to mark certain tax codes as "Capital Goods" relevant.

Configuration path: SAP Customizing Implementation Guide -> Cross-Application Components -> General Application Functions -> eDocument -> Country/Region-Specific Settings -> Spain -> Settings for Electronic IGIC Register Books With SII -> Assign Additional Attributes to Input Tax Codes for IGIC (SSCUI 107267)

In this customizing activity, you can select "Capital Goods" in the "Attributes" column.

When a tax code is marked as Capital Goods, invoices using this tax code will populate the XML tag:

<BienInversion>S</BienInversion>

Adjustment documents (REBU and REAV)

The special VAT schemas REBU (used goods) or REAV (travel agencies) calculate IGIC and tax base amounts based on estimated profit margins for the invoicing period. At year-end, margins are recalculated, which may require adjustments.

(*) This calculation is not part of the SAP standard.

Once the new margin is calculated, adjustments to IGIC and tax base amounts (positive or negative) can be reported to the Tax Agency using the new document type “AJ”.

Configuration Path: SAP Customizing Implementation Guide -> Cross-Application Components -> General Application Functions -> eDocument -> Country/Region-Specific Settings -> Spain -> Settings for Electronic IGIC Register Books With SII -> Assign SII Attributes to Document Types for IGIC (SSCUI 102992). Mark the relevant accounting document type as "AJ".

 

The IGIC adjustment will be reported as follows:

 

Validation Rules:

  • Fields not reported in the XML message:
    • <FechaOperacion> (Tax fulfillment)
    • Block <Contraparte> (receiver)
  • Mandatory fields:
    • <TipoImpositivo> 
    • <BaseImponible>
    • <CuotaRepercutida>
  • Fixed fields:
    • <TipoFactura> is "AJ"
    • <ClaveRegimenEspecialOTrascendencia> must be either “03” (REBU) or “05” (REAV)
    • <TipoDesglose> must contain only <DesgloseFactura>
    • <TipoNoExenta> = “S1” 

 

 

 

Disclaimer

This blog post is intended for informational purposes only and reflects a simplified configuration approach based on current legal and system understanding. It does not constitute legal or implementation advice. SAP system behavior may vary depending on version, scope, and customer-specific settings. For full compliance and implementation support, please consult your SAP implementation partner or legal advisor.

 

Related links

In case of additional questions, you can refer to the official SAP documentation:

  • Electronic Tax Register Books with SII in S/4HANA Public Cloud
  • Electronic Tax Register Books with SII in S/4HANA Private Cloud
  • Electronic Tax Register Books with SII in ERP

Other SII tips and community discussions:

  • Spain – SAP Document and Reporting Compliance → Related Links → Community Section

entry.title: Statutory Reporting and EFD-Reinf: Mass Rectification for the R-4000 Series
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community,

We're excited to share a new feature in the EFD-Reinf report for Brazil, specifically for users of the Statutory Reporting framework: Mass Rectification for the R-4000 Series. This enhancement is set to transform how you manage corrections for the EFD-Reinf R-4000 series.

Introducing Mass Rectification in R-4000 Series

With the new Mass Rectification functionality, users can now easily generate rectification files for multiple events at once during the Correction Phase of your reporting tasks. This means faster and more efficient handling of corrections when you need to rectify several events for a given company and branch.

How It Works

When running the Brazil EFD-Reinf Periodic Files task, you'll notice a new Run Mass Rectification checkbox in the selection criteria popup, as seen below:

Here’s what you need to know about the options:

  • File ID for Rectification:
    • When a specific File ID is entered in this field, the system will create the rectification file only for the provided File ID (i.e., only the selected event will be corrected). 
  • Run Mass Rectification Checkbox:
    • If you select the Run Mass Rectification flag without entering a File ID, rectification files will be generated for all eligible R-4000 series events for the specified Company Code and Business Place.
    • This is especially useful when multiple corrections are needed across several events, saving you significant manual effort!

Additionally, you can schedule or run this task immediately with the standard Run Options for background processing that is recommend for large volume of files, making it even easier to fit rectification into your processes.

Why Use Mass Rectification?

  • Faster Corrections: Generate rectification files for many events in a single run.
  • Greater Flexibility: Correct either specific events by ID or all relevant events for your company and branch at once.
  • Improved Compliance: Stay up to date with changing requirements and ensure your data is always accurate.

Learn More

To explore this new functionality and stay updated on further enhancements, check out these SAP Help Portal resources:

  • Document and Reporting Compliance
  • EFD-Reinf Report

 

We value your feedback!
If you have any questions or suggestions for future topics, please leave your comment below.

See you in the next post!



Statutory Reporting for Brazil Team

entry.title: Mass Actions in Statutory Reporting - Enhancing Compliance Management
entry.content:
The Evolution of the Tax Function 

Not too long ago, multinational companies relied on a more local approach for managing tax compliance. Each country had its own dedicated tax expert, someone who truly understood the local regulations and handled everything from VAT returns to audit responses within their territory. This model worked well in many ways. It offered deep local knowledge and quick responsiveness when needed. However, it also came with its own set of challenges, especially around consistency, oversight, and cost. 

As businesses expanded and sought greater efficiency, many shifted towards a centralized model. Shared service centres were established to manage tax and statutory reporting across multiple countries from a single location. This transition brought clear advantages. Processes became more streamlined, control improved, and costs were reduced. At the same time, it introduced a new challenge, teams that previously focused on just one country were now responsible for a global compliance portfolio. 

In this new environment, shared service teams need tools that help them scale their efforts, automate routine tasks, and ensure consistency across regions. Mass Actions and Scheduling in Statutory Reporting address these challenges for global teams.  

The Accountant’s Daily Reality—Before and After 

Before these features, here is what a day looked like during the VAT season: 

  • Log in. 
  • Manually generate reports for each country. 
  • Review and validate them. 
  • Submit them one by one. 
  • Chase down approvals. 
  • Update submission statuses. 
  • Track what was accepted, what failed, and what needed to be resubmitted. 

Repeat this for 5 reports per country × 10 countries. That is 50 reporting tasks per month. 

Mass Actions 

With Mass Actions, we can now execute bulk actions across all reports in one go. The steps include: - 

  1. Selecting the reports we want. 
  2. Choosing the action - Generate, Send Report Run for Approval, Update Report Run Submission Status or Submit Report Run. 
  3. Hitting "Generate/Send/Update/Submit". 

SAP handles the rest. 

Need to manage reports for France, Norway, Columbia and Poland whenever the local regulations demand? Instead of processing each report manually and individually, Mass Actions allow Business users to handle all these requirements together by selecting the relevant reports, executing the needed steps, and letting the system take care of the rest.

 

Problem We are Solving 

With Mass actions we have 

  • Reduced Manual Effort 
  • Lower Operational Costs 
  • Increased Productivity 

Here is a simplified overview of a monthly VAT process flow using Mass Actions: 

 

1. Select Required Tasks

 

2. Choose Action - Generate Report Run

 

 

3. Execute Reporting Tasks in Bulk

 

4. Review Logs to track progress

With Mass actions we have: 

  •  Efficiency 

Save hours of manual, repetitive work with bulk processing capabilities. 

Streamline compliance activities across countries and report types from a single interface. 

  •  Scalability 

Easily manage a growing volume of reports 

Support centralized operations across multiple jurisdictions without additional overhead. 

  • Flexibility 

Adapt to various reporting requirements across entities, countries, and regulatory formats. 

Configure actions and schedules to fit both legal mandates and internal business timelines. 

To Summarize 

Mass Actions in Statutory Reporting provides a practical way to manage large volumes of statutory reports efficiently. They enable centralized processing, reduce manual effort, and ensure that recurring tasks run reliably in the background helping organizations stay compliant across multiple countries and reporting cycles. 

The follow-up section of this blog, which explores the Scheduling feature of Run Statutory Reporting, is available via the link provided below.

 

https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/mass-actions-in-statutory-reporting-part-2-scheduling-for-timely-execution/ba-p/14273540

entry.title: Mass Actions in Statutory Reporting – Part 2: Scheduling for Timely Execution
entry.content:
Introduction 

In the previous blog, we explored how Mass Actions simplify statutory reporting by allowing users to perform a single action across multiple tasks. This feature reduces manual effort across tasks. 

Among the available options, Schedule Mass Action adds even more value by letting users automate actions to run at a specific time aligned with reporting deadlines. In this follow-up, we will dive into how scheduling ensures timely compliance in your reporting process. 

Let us take a closer look at how to set it up and make the most of it. 

Scheduling Mass Actions. 

Let us say we want to generate all monthly VAT reports on the 1st of every month, review them on the 2nd, and submit them by the 5th. We set this up once, and it runs like clockwork. 

Even when employees are away or simply overseeing the process, reports continue to generate and queue automatically in the background. The system knows. 

The scheduling process flow follows three targeted steps: 

1. Choose the required Job Template – 
Choose a job template and assign a clear job name for easy identification. It works on two scheduling modes: 

a.  Schedule reporting actions to recur on fixed calendar dates: Ideal for known deadlines (e.g., 1st of every month). 

b.  Schedule reporting action to recur per period based on different reporting deadlines: Perfect for fiscal cycles or quarterly returns. 

  

This dual-template approach exists to accommodate the different reporting rhythms and regulatory requirements faced by multinational organizations. 

2. Scheduling Options 
Define a start date/time, an optional end date, and a recurrence pattern (e.g., monthly, quarterly). 

3. Set the required parameters 
Specify essential details such as the reporting entity, report type, or period - tailored to your use case. 

Once scheduled, your reports run automatically. Users can focus on higher-value activities, knowing compliance processing happens reliably in the background. 

With Scheduling, we can now: 

  • Ensures Timely Submissions 

Schedules actions to run at the right time, helping meet reporting deadlines without manual effort. 

  • Reduces Manual Workload 

Eliminates the need to trigger actions manually, especially useful for recurring or large-volume reports. 

  • Improves Efficiency and Planning 

Allows users to plan by scheduling tasks in advance, reducing last-minute pressure. 

 

To summarize 

Scheduling in Mass Actions allows users to automate statutory reporting tasks based on specific timelines. Instead of executing actions like Generate, Submit, or Approve immediately, users can schedule them to run at a future date and time, often aligned with reporting deadlines. This is especially useful when managing recurring or time-sensitive reports across multiple entities or periods. 

Hope after reading this blog post it will provide some useful insights about the features – Mass Actions & Scheduling. Feel free to provide your feedback, suggestions, questions in comments below.

entry.title: KSeF 2.0: Setup and Integrate Your System with the Cloud Edition
entry.content:
This blog post was updated on December 23, 2025, to include the latest changes related to the pre-production and production environment.

The original plan from the Poland authorities to introduce mandatory e-invoices through KSeF in 2024 was postponed. The delay was used to rebuild the infrastructure and launch KSeF 2.0. With that, some of the changes are reflected in the following:

  • The new KSeF 2.0 is not compatible with KSeF 1.0, meaning it significantly impacts how you setup and integrate your system.
  • A new FA (3) schema version for electronic invoice formatting is introduced.
  • The authentication method based on token will be phased out by 2026. As a result, SAP will support only certificate-based authentication for KSeF 2.0 (only tokens were supported for KSeF 1.0).

You can already setup your business system for the new invoice format required with KSef 2.0 and update the integration requirements to use SAP Document and Reporting Compliance, cloud edition. 

Be aware that KSeF has different environments that should be assigned to different service plans of the cloud edition, as follows:

  • KSeF 2.0 Test Environment - Test Plan of the cloud edition
  • KSeF 2.0 Demo (Pre-Prod) Environment - Test Plan of the cloud edition
  • KSeF 2.0 Production Environment: Standard Plan of the cloud edition

Please note that existing integration remains applicable for production environment of KSeF 1.0 until the legal mandate comes into effect, at the end of January 2026. You can already test new integration with test and pre-production environment of KSeF 2.0. Be aware of the period indicated by KSeF to apply changes to your production environment.

 

Depending on when you integrated your business system with the cloud edition, the steps to setup your system for KSeF 2.0 can vary. Before starting, make sure the E-Invoices Through KSeF (PL) process is active in the Activate Processes app - the process that should be activated is the same if you configured your system for KSeF 1.0 (in this case, it is already active), or if you are configuring your system for KSeF 2.0 now.

For the integration, you need to perform the general integration settings. For that, consider according to your business system: 

  • Integrating All Other Processes and Countries/Regions with SAP ERP 
  • Integrating All Other Processes and Countries/Regions with SAP S/4HANA or SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 
  • Integrating All Other Processes and Countries/Regions with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

Please, also consider the following:

  • You should perform all the steps described under the Establishing Connection from Cloud Edition to Business System section, including configuring the Cloud Connector. This is a technical prerequisite and does not require additional license.
  • If you use processes other than Peppol Exchange, Argentina, Romania, Serbia, or Slovakia, you might have done these steps already and there are no additional steps for now.
  • If you have onboarded the cloud edition after April 2023, you don’t need to create a new service binding when performing the steps for the new integration. 
  • Once these settings are completed, the system automatically sets the integration with KSeF 2.0.

If you have configured your system for KSeF 1.0, you have already made process-specific configuration using your NIP number. The system ignores that configuration, but you can also delete it, if you prefer. For KSeF 2.0, you can find detailed information by accessing the KSeF 2.0: Certificate & Authorization for Establishing Connection with the Cloud Edition blog post.

Besides the integration with the cloud edition, there are steps that you have to perform in your business systems related to the new invoice format.

For SAP ERP, SAP S/4HANA, or SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition, see the following:

  • Implement SAP Note 367668.
  • Do the configuration to adapt your business system to the legal mandate. For more information, see:
    • SAP S/4HANA or SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition  
    • SAP ERP

Even if you already implemented KSeF 1.0, please review the complete Customizing section, as new configuration nodes and new configuration values have been introduced with KSeF 2.0.

  • In the Define Process Communication Through Cloud Services Customizing activity, update the Service option to Cloud Edition: Standard Integration. 

In your productive system, that this setting should be made only in the period indicated by KSeF to move to their production environment.

For SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, see the following:

  • Do the configuration to adapt your business system to the legal mandate. The business system documentation is available in the PDF file delivered with SAP Notes 3687266 and 3689736.

Even if you already implemented KSeF 1.0, please review the complete Customizing section, as new configuration nodes and new configuration values have been introduced with KSeF 2.0.

  • In the Define Process Communication Through Cloud Services configuration step, update the Service option to Cloud Edition: Standard Integration. 

In your productive system, that this setting should be made only in the period indicated by KSeF to move to their production environment.

 

For more information, you can access the Regulatory Change Manager for Mandatory e-Invoicing through KSeF in Poland. 

Best regards,

entry.title: Document and Reporting Compliance Cloud Edition: A New Generation of Global Tax Compliance
entry.content:
In a world where governments are rapidly digitizing tax controls, companies must ensure real-time reporting, accurate e-invoicing, and seamless integration with local authorities. SAP has long supported these needs through its Document and Reporting Compliance (DRC) solution embedded in SAP S/4HANA.

As regulatory demands increase and cloud adoption accelerates, SAP introduced Document and Reporting Compliance, Cloud Edition—a next-generation, cloud-native platform designed to help enterprises respond faster, comply globally, and scale efficiently.

This article explains both solutions and highlights the key differences that set the Cloud Edition apart.

 

What Is SAP Document and Reporting Compliance (DRC)?

DRC is the integrated compliance framework within SAP S/4HANA, built to support:

  • Electronic invoicing (eDocuments)

  • Legal reporting (SAF-T, VAT, Intrastat, etc.)

  • Indirect tax submissions

  • Real-time government integrations

  • Audit and compliance workflows

DRC leverages SAP S/4HANA’s core capabilities, using:

  • Embedded data models

  • Fiori apps

  • Integration with finance and logistics

  • Local add-ons for country-specific mandates

It is ideal for companies that run S/4HANA (on-premise, private cloud or public cloud) and want compliance deeply integrated into transactional flows.

What Is Document and Reporting Compliance, Cloud Edition?

DRC Cloud Edition is SAP’s standalone, cloud-native compliance platform built on SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP).

It is designed to:

  • Support global e-invoicing mandates

  • Manage content-rich regulatory reporting

  • Centralize compliance across multiple ERP systems

  • Provide API-based connections to government platforms

  • Deliver continuous updates through the cloud

Unlike DRC embedded in S/4HANA, the Cloud Edition does not depend on the ERP release cycle, allowing SAP to push compliance updates faster and support new regulations more rapidly.

Key Differentiators: DRC vs. DRC Cloud Edition

Below are the main areas where the Cloud Edition differentiates itself from the traditional DRC embedded in S/4HANA.

1. Deployment Architecture

Aspect DRC (Embedded) DRC Cloud Edition
LocationRuns inside SAP S/4HANARuns outside ERP, on SAP BTP
DependenciesTied to ERP version & upgradesIndependent of ERP release cycle
UpdatesDelivered with S/4HANA feature packsContinuous cloud updates

Benefit: Faster adoption of new regulatory requirements with minimal impact on the ERP.

2. Multi-ERP and Non-SAP Integration

Aspect DRC DRC Cloud Edition
Supported systemsPrimarily SAP S/4HANAMulti-ERP, multi-system, including non-SAP
ConsolidationUsually per ERP instanceCentralized compliance hub

Benefit: Ideal for companies with multiple ERPs, global rollouts, or hybrid landscapes.

3. Scalability and Global Coverage

  • DRC Cloud Edition can scale more easily across countries.

  • SAP delivers regulatory content globally through cloud content packages.

  • Government API connectivity is managed centrally.

Benefit: Enterprises expand into new jurisdictions without large ERP projects.

4. Government Integrations and Connectivity

DRC Cloud Edition offers:

  • Managed API gateways to tax authorities

  • Continuous monitoring of government system changes

  • Central message tracking across countries

Benefit: Reduces IT workload and ensures higher resilience for e-invoicing and e-reporting.

5. Innovation, AI and Extensibility

Because it sits on SAP BTP, DRC Cloud Edition can leverage:

  • AI-driven anomaly detection

  • Intelligent validation of documents

  • Faster extensibility via low-code tools

  • Cloud automation services

Benefit: More innovation potential compared to the ERP-embedded DRC.

6. Upgrade Effort and Maintenance

Aspect DRC (Embedded) DRC Cloud Edition
Customer effortMust test with ERP upgradesMinimal customer testing
UpdatesPeriodicContinuous and automatic
MaintenanceShared between ERP team and tax complianceFully handled in the cloud

Benefit: Lower TCO and faster compliance readiness.

When to Choose Each Solution?

Choose DRC (Embedded in S/4HANA) if:

  • You want compliance tightly integrated into transactional finance and logistics.

  • You prefer a single solution inside S/4HANA.

  • You operate primarily in countries already supported within DRC.

Choose DRC Cloud Edition if:

  • You need global multi-country e-invoicing with fast deployment.

  • You operate multiple ERPs or hybrid landscapes.

  • You want rapid response to changing government mandates.

  • You need a future-proof cloud strategy with continuous innovation.

Conclusion

SAP Document and Reporting Compliance Cloud Edition represents the evolution of digital tax compliance—faster, more scalable, and designed for a global, multi-system world.

While the traditional DRC embedded in S/4HANA remains a strong and deeply integrated option, the Cloud Edition expands capabilities with:

  • Cloud-native architecture

  • Faster regulatory updates

  • Centralized global management

  • Support for multiple ERPs

  • Continuous innovation via SAP BTP

Together, both solutions equip organizations to meet today’s regulatory environment and future-proof their compliance landscape.

entry.title: KSeF 2.0 Test Environment: Automate the Retrieval of Electronic Documents with the Cloud Edition
entry.content:
You are setting up your system for the new invoice format required for KSeF 2.0 and want to understand how to test automated retrieval of invoices from the tax authority portal to achieve end-to-end processing of electronic documents.

With the Schedule Jobs app in SAP Document and Reporting Compliance, cloud edition, you can create one job that automates the retrieval of supplier or self-billing invoices from the tax authority portal to your business system (for example, SAP S/4HANA or SAP ERP) . This makes the following activities in your business system obsolete:

  • Processing eDocument Inbound Messages
  • Processing Incoming Messages with Additional Filters
  • Processing eDocument Status Message
  • Processing Status Messages for Multiple eDocuments

Meaning, you no longer use the eDocument Inbound Message Handler for these activities. Instead, you use Schedule Jobs app.

How it works?

  1. You schedule a job in the SAP Document and Reporting Compliance, cloud edition. The system automatically creates a request based on the job configuration.
  2. The cloud edition takes invoice data from Krajowy System e-Faktur (KSeF), a platform from the Polish tax authority used to exchange electronic invoices.
  3. The cloud edition decrypts retrieved invoices, creates visualization as PDF files and pushes to the destination business system selected for the job.
  4. The business system creates the electronic document and updates its status. The XML (FA(3)) and PDF files are available in the history of the electronic document. Here you can also check if any duplicate documents were retrieved.
    Note: To see the attached XML (FA(3)) and PDF files, select the electronic document and open Attachments in the Manage Electronic Documents app, or History in the eDocument Cockpit transaction.

Test Use Cases

In this blog, I share details on two key scenarios for downloading invoices that you might want to apply with the Schedule Jobs app:

  • Downloading purchase invoices
  • Downloading sales invoices for self-billing

Prerequisites

You have already performed the general integration settings for test environment as described in this blog: KSeF 2.0 Test Environment: Setup and Integrate Your System with the Cloud Edition.

Now, you can test configuring automated jobs for retrieving your invoices from tax authority portal using the Schedule Jobs app.  To access the app, go to the SAP Document and Reporting Compliance, cloud edition launchpad in your associated SAP BTP subaccount. See Scheduling Jobs.

Configuration is guided through a step-by-step wizard:

  1. Define the general settings for the job, by selecting:
    • Process Flow:  Retrieving Documents for E-Invoices Through KseF (PL)
    • Identification Number: Select the NIP number you have set for communication type E-Invoices Through KSeF 2.0 (PL). See Managing Communication Settings.

  2. Configure additional properties required by KSeF 2.0 to provide the data to the cloud edition. This is where you pay attention to achieve the scenarios.

    Scenario 1: You want to schedule job to retrieve invoices where your company is the buyer.

    • subjectType: Subject2 (Buyer)
    • dateType: Issue (Use for KSeF 2.0 test environment).
      Note: Later, for production, it’s recommended to use PermanentStorage (based on archival date) to avoid missing invoices.

    Scenario 2: You want to schedule a job to retrieve invoices issued under self-invoicing mode where your company acts as the seller.

    • subjectType: Subject1 (Seller)
    • dateType: Issue (Use for KSeF 2.0 test environment).
      Note: Later, for production, it’s recommended to use PermanentStorage (based on archival date) to avoid missing invoices.
    • sellerNIP: Your company NIP number
    • isSelfInvoicing: Select the checkbox

  3. Define the frequency of your job. Example configuration can be:
    • Every 2 hours – the cloud edition will send a request for retrieving the invoices every 2 hours and will get the invoices created in between.
    • One-Time – you can use this to get the invoices for a certain period in the past, for example, the period before the first run of your recurring job.

      Note: You can have only one recurring job per combination of process flow and identification number and as many one-time jobs as you need. For example, If you already have created a recurring job for Retrieving Documents for E-Invoices Through KseF (PL) for NIP number 123XXXXXXX, you will be able to create only one-time jobs. To create a recurring job with different parameters, you must first delete the existing one.

  4.  Select the destination you created for the business system in which you want to receive the documents. See Setting Up Connectivity.

Once you save your configuration, you can monitor the results of your job runs – time details, status, results, troubleshooting steps. See Viewing Results of a Job Run.

For more information on KSeF 2.0 related features covered by SAP, you can access the Regulatory Change Manager for Mandatory e-Invoicing through KSeF in Poland.

entry.title: SAP & 1099 Reporting: How S/4HANA Supports US Tax Compliance
entry.content:
1. Overview of 1099 / U.S. Withholding Tax Reporting in SAP

1.1 What is 1099 Reporting?

In the U.S., businesses must issue 1099 forms to certain payees (vendors, service providers, contractors) when payments meet IRS thresholds, commonly $600 per year for non-employee compensation. The forms report payment amounts and are submitted to the IRS.

1099 covers many categories:

  • 1099-NEC: Nonemployee compensation (services, contractors)

  • 1099-MISC: Other income types (rent, royalties, prizes)

  • 1099-INT: Interest income

  • 1099-K: Payment card or third-party network transactions

  • 1099-G: Government payments, such as unemployment benefits

  • 1042-S: Payments to foreign persons or entities subject to withholding

A robust system must handle multiple vendor types, vendor master data, withholding tax codes, and aggregation logic for accurate year-end reporting.

1.2 SAP’s 1099 / Withholding Tax Functionality

In legacy SAP ERP or ECC, companies often used built-in withholding-tax and 1099 reporting functionality. With S/4HANA, SAP introduced improved compliance reporting via the Document and Reporting Compliance (DRC) module. This integrates statutory and withholding tax reporting, including U.S. 1099 and 1042-S, directly in S/4HANA.

S/4HANA supports generation of print forms for 1099/1042-S reports (e.g., 1099-MISC, 1099-INT, 1099-K, 1042-S) out of the box. The “Generic Withholding Tax Report” or “Run Statutory Reports” function in DRC enables organizations to comply with IRS reporting requirements.

SAP maintains structured tables to hold 1099 statutory reporting data, ensuring vendor and payment information is stored consistently for extraction, reconciliation, and audit purposes.

2. Core Components in S/4HANA for 1099 Reporting

2.1 Vendor / Business Partner Master Data

  • Vendors or business partners must have correct tax identifiers (TIN, SSN, EIN) registered under the relevant tax category for 1099 eligibility.

  • For foreign vendors requiring 1099-NEC or 1042-S reporting, tax numbers and treaty status must be correctly maintained.

  • Vendor role assignment must be configured correctly so the DRC module knows which suppliers are 1099-eligible.

Accurate vendor master data is the foundation of successful 1099 reporting.

2.2 Withholding Tax Configuration & Codes

  • The SAP withholding tax framework must capture payments subject to withholding or 1099 reporting.

  • Withholding tax codes must be defined and assigned to the relevant 1099 or 1042-S form type, ensuring that SAP correctly identifies reportable payments.

  • Proper mapping to G/L accounts and configuration of threshold rules is essential to avoid missing or incorrect 1099 reporting.

2.3 Statutory Reporting Module (DRC)

  • S/4HANA’s DRC module provides a Fiori application for running statutory reports. It generates 1099-MISC, 1099-NEC, 1099-K, and 1042-S reports by reading data from withholding tax ledgers, vendor master records, and payment documents.

  • The module aggregates and formats output according to IRS specifications, ensuring compliance with print or electronic filing requirements.

  • SAP provides updates to reflect changes in IRS rules, such as the reintroduction of 1099-NEC in 2020.

2.4 Database Storage: Structured Tables

  • S/4HANA uses dedicated tables to store 1099 reporting data, including vendor IDs, document references, withholding tax details, and report totals.

  • HANA-native storage ensures high performance, fast data retrieval, and easier extraction for e-filing or auditing purposes.

2.5 Output / Filing

  • DRC supports generating IRS-compliant 1099 forms for print and electronic formats.

  • For advanced compliance, S/4HANA can integrate with third-party solutions for electronic filing and tax reporting automation.

  • Integration simplifies multi-state compliance and large-volume reporting.

3. Key Challenges & Known Issues in 1099 Reporting on S/4HANA

3.1 Missing or Incorrect Tax Numbers

  • Missing or incorrectly maintained TINs or SSNs in vendor master data are a leading cause of 1099 reporting failures.

  • Vendor roles and tax categories must be accurately configured to ensure correct inclusion in 1099 runs.

3.2 Withholding / Payment Configuration Issues

  • Payments may not be captured in 1099 reporting if withholding tax codes are missing or incorrectly assigned.

  • Cleared payments without proper withholding tax line items can lead to incomplete reporting.

3.3 Foreign Vendors & 1042-S Reporting

  • Payments to foreign vendors must be distinguished from domestic 1099 reporting.

  • Proper classification, treaty status, and withholding tax codes are necessary to avoid reporting errors.

3.4 IRS Rule Changes

  • Recent IRS changes, such as the separation of nonemployee compensation to 1099-NEC, require updates to SAP configuration and reporting templates.

3.5 System Limitations

  • In certain cases, foreign vendors may be incorrectly included or excluded in 1099 runs.

  • Layout issues in generated forms, such as missing recipient copies, can occur if configuration is not properly maintained.

  • Migration from legacy SAP or non-SAP systems may introduce data inconsistencies affecting 1099 reporting.

4. Implementing 1099 Reporting in S/4HANA — Step-by-Step Guide

4.1 Implementation Steps

  1. Enable Withholding Tax / 1099 Feature Scope

    • Activate statutory reporting and U.S.-specific features.

  2. Vendor Master Data Review & Cleanup

    • Verify TINs, vendor roles, and U.S. tax categories.

    • Ensure foreign vendors needing 1042-S reporting are correctly classified.

  3. Define Withholding Tax Codes

    • Create or configure codes for each 1099 or 1042-S type.

    • Map to correct G/L accounts and reporting categories.

  4. Configure Statutory Reporting

    • Set parameters for company code, reporting year, vendor selection, and tax number filters.

    • Test in a sandbox system before production.

  5. Test Data Scenarios

    • Include domestic and foreign vendors, cross-currency payments, partial payments, and credit memos.

  6. Generate Output

    • Run DRC reports to create IRS-compliant 1099/1042-S forms.

    • Validate totals, vendor information, and format compliance.

  7. Reconciliation & Audit

    • Reconcile SAP payments and 1099 totals.

    • Archive master data snapshots and final output for audit.

5. Enhancements & Integrations

5.1 Integration with External Compliance Tools

  • Integration with third-party tax engines can help automate e-filing, multi-state reporting, and complex compliance requirements.

5.2 Custom Reporting & Analytics

  • Structured data allows creation of custom reports or dashboards to monitor 1099 exposure, vendor payments, and audit readiness.

5.3 Multi-Entity / Global Compliance

  • Organizations with U.S. and non-U.S. subsidiaries can consolidate statutory reporting in a single SAP-based compliance hub.

6. Real-Life Lessons & Common Pitfalls

  1. Incorrect Vendor Master Data — Ensure TINs and vendor roles are accurate.

  2. Payments Without Correct Withholding — Enforce AP process discipline.

  3. Foreign Vendor Misclassification — Use proper 1042-S settings.

  4. IRS Form Changes — Update configuration for new forms and thresholds.

  5. High Volume Payments — Optimize HANA-native storage and extraction.

  6. Non-SAP Payments — Ensure external payments are captured for 1099 compliance.

7. Third-Party Tools: When to Consider

  • SAP S/4HANA + DRC can handle core 1099 reporting.

  • For complex or high-volume scenarios, external tools can provide e-filing, vendor outreach, and multi-state automation.

  • Hybrid approaches combine SAP data integrity with external compliance automation.

8. Known Issues & SAP Limitations

  • Incorrect inclusion of foreign vendors

  • Layout issues in generated forms

  • Migration challenges from legacy systems

  • Empty reports despite payments due to configuration changes

9. Best-Practice Recommendations

  1. Maintain clean vendor master data year-round.

  2. Standardize AP and payment processes.

  3. Run periodic mock 1099 runs.

  4. Centralize compliance governance.

  5. Leverage third-party compliance tools where necessary.

  6. Archive all data and reports for audit purposes.

  7. Stay current with IRS and SAP updates.

10. Future Outlook

  • Deeper integration with external tax engines

  • Improved foreign vendor and 1042-S support

  • Enhanced analytics and dashboards

  • Automated compliance workflows

  • Global compliance consolidation

Conclusion

SAP S/4HANA with Document & Reporting Compliance provides a unified, auditable, and scalable approach for 1099 reporting. Success depends on accurate vendor data, proper configuration, disciplined AP processes, and governance. Proper implementation allows SAP to become the backbone of your U.S. statutory compliance, ensuring accurate and timely reporting for all 1099 and 1042-S obligations.

entry.title: euBP in Germany: Generating a Certificate File in Germany’s ITSG Trust Center Portal
entry.content:
• Introduction
  • About ITSG
  • Registration at ITSG Trust Center Portal
  • Step 1 Enter Subscriber Number
  • Step 2 Enter Personal Data of Contact Person
  • Step 3 Confirm Email Address
  • Step 4 Start Identity Verification
  • Step 5 Complete Identity Verification
  • Step 6 Confirm Company Address
  • Step 7 Select Billing Address and Delivery
  • Step 8 Registration as a Collection Center
  • Step 9 Certificate Request Inbound Check
  • Generation of Electronic Keys
  • Submitting the Files to the Trust Center
  • Inbound Check of Certificate Request
  • Step 10 Enter a Tagging Code
  • Transferring Certified Participant Keys and Activation
  • Configuring the Key Data and Certificate File in SAP BTP Cockpit

Note:  The steps and processes described here are accurate as of the time of writing, but it's essential to stay updated with any changes on the ITSG portal that may affect this procedure. Detailed description in German can be found here: https://www.itsg.de/wp-content/uploads/Trust-Center-Registrierungsportal.pdf 

Introduction

In this blog post, I will guide you through the process of generating a certificate file in ITSG Trust Center portal using POSTIDENT. This certificate is essential for establishing a connection between the SAP Document and Reporting Compliance, cloud edition (hereafter referred to as the "cloud edition") and the German pension insurance authority's system. This will allow you to submit the required financial accounting data from your business system SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition integrated with the cloud edition to the pension insurance authority's system. The requirement is also known as euBP, an abbreviation of the local name Elektronisch unterstützte Betriebsprüfung, or "electronically supported company audit" in English.

About ITSG

ITSG, which stands for Information technology service point of the statutory health insurance GmbH, operates the ITSG Trust Center to create and manage certificates and facilitate secure electronic data exchange in the health and social services sectors. 

Registration at ITSG Trust Center Portal

Access the registration portal of the ITSG Trust Center using the address https://registrierungsportal.itsg.de/regportal/client/de/login . For a new activity, choose the "Register" button and for an existing activity, choose the "Log On" button.

Log on the portal

Step 1 Enter Subscriber Number

First enter the company number, the special sender number or the paying office number for the application as a unique participant number that is to be used in electronic data exchange.

Enter subscriber number

Step 2 Enter Personal Data of Contact Person

The entry of the personal data of the contact person is divided into two areas: contact data and logon data.

Enter contact data

 

 

Enter logon data

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Note: The first name and last name of the contact person must be entered in full according to the valid German identity card, valid German passport or the official identity cards and passport corresponding to the German identity card. If the name is incomplete or deviates, this leads to a rejection in the registration portal during identity verification after a POSTIDENT procedure.

Step 3 Confirm Email Address

After entering the contact data and logon data, a confirmation e-mail is sent to the specified e-mail address with an activation link for confirmation.

confirmation page

After confirmation, the logon can be performed with the logon data.

Logon after confirmation

Step 4 Start Identity Verification

The contact person must use the registration portal to carry out identification with a POSTIDENT procedure at Deutsche Post AG. The postal identification variant is only possible in Germany. Alternatively, online identification function with online ID function is supported, nut only a German identity card with activated electronic identity (eID) is permitted. 

More information can be found: https://www.deutschepost.de/de/p/postident/privatkunden/faq.html

Identity verification

Step 5 Complete Identity Verification

After the identification has been carried out using a POSTIDENT procedure, the registration portal checks the electronic confirmation from the POSTIDENT system to determine whether the first names and last names entered in step 2 (possibly also double names and titles for last names) match completely and in the sequence specified in the identification documentation. 

Complete identity verification

 After successful identification, you must log on to the registration portal again to continue the further steps. If the identity verification was not completed successfully, you can start a new registration with a new identification using the “Restart Registration” button.

Step 6 Confirm Company Address

The applicant's address is checked against lists of the issuing agencies and must then be confirmed by the contact person. If the displayed address is correct and current, click the “Address is correct” button to proceed to the next step. At the end of the certification, an activation code for activating the security module is sent to the assigned company address of the applicant.


If your company is based outside Germany, you have the option of selecting the country here. As a contact person, you can also enter your name and, for example, manually add department to the displayed address of the applicant.

If the displayed address does not correspond to the actual company address of the applicant, a generated release letter cannot be delivered correctly later in the registration process. In this case, please arrange your adjustment of the company address at the issuing agency for your trading partner number.

Step 7 Select Billing Address and Delivery

By default, your invoice will use the previously confirmed applicant company address from step 6. If the invoice is to be sent to a different billing address, use a different billing address and enter the billing address. 

Use a different billing address

 Enter address

As an alternative, you can choose a delivery by e-mail. To do this, set a checkmark for "Use electronic delivery of invoice" and specify the e-mail address.

Electronic delivery

Step 8 Registration as a Collection Center

Optionally, you can register as a reporting office to transfer notifications for other company numbers in the employer procedure or for other institute indicators in the service provider procedure.

Step 9 Certificate Request Inbound Check

The registration portal checks in the background whether the applicant has submitted a technical certificate request that was created using the security module to the Trust Center. The execution of this step is divided into the three substeps: Generation of Electronic Keys, Transfer of Files to Trust Center, and Receipt Check of Certificate Request.

Generation of Electronic Keys

A GUID transaction number (GUID for short) is now assigned, which is used as a reference between the data in the registration portal and the technical data for generating the certificate from the applicant's system. The GUID consists of 36 characters. It is recommend that you use a technically supported copy and paste of the characters to avoid spelling errors or character shifts.

GUID

 Working with the Separate Security Module

The security module is essential for applying for the electronic certificate at the ITSG Trust Center. This operation on the applicant's system is not supported by the registration portal. Therefore, you're recommended to actively log off the registration portal. Otherwise, the logoff takes place automatically.

In the security module, the key data for generating the electronic key pair (consisting of the public and private key) of the applicant must be entered manually and a certificate must be applied for. This key data must clearly match the request data entered in the registration portal. 

The following are the key data required:

· Participant number - alternatively, company number, special sender number, paying office number, etc.

· Applicant Name (Company Name)

· Contact Full Name

After entering the required information, the security module generates the key pair (consisting of public and private key) with the hash code of the request key required for certification (public key of the participant in the request file). The private key remains in the IT system of the applicant.

The generated request key is stored by the security module in a so-called Request file (p10 format) to check the hash code by the contact person for a match in a subsequent request step (example extract of a hash code: E1D07A4B.….FC781).

The security module generates a so-called safety module. Hash code file (pdf format) with the hash code in SHA256 format. This contains the following information for a unique assignment:

  • The participant number - alternatively, company number, test company number, sender number, paying office number, etc.
  • Name of the company (company name)
  • Contact Name
  • Hash Code of Request Key (SHA256 Format)

Submitting the Files to the Trust Center

After the security module has generated the electronic key and a PDF file with the hash code has been saved, the two files must be transferred to the Trust Center with the request file (for example, 12345678.p10) and the hash code. The transfer of the files to the Trust Center depends on the selected request form and the supported functions in the used software (with or without OSTC online interface).

If the software used does not support the OSTC online interface of the Trust Center, you must manually transfer the two files with the request file and the hash code (PDF file) to the trust center. Optionally, a self-declaration for a reporting office (PDF file) can be transferred in addition to the request.

Initial applications without OSTC online interface

Call up the Web address https://www.itsg-trust.de/zap/home in a browser.

Initial application without OSTC interface

 To uniquely assign the files to be transferred, you must specify the GUID transaction number (see substep Generation of Electronic Keys). After this, the three files are transferred to the Trust Center. The portal confirms the successful transfer with an internal transaction number (e.g. UP123456). 

  • Request File
  • Hash Code File
  • Self-declaration reporting office (optional) 

Initial application or online subsequent application via the OSTC online interface
For an online application using the OSTC online interface, all required application data and components (without self-declaration reporting office) are transferred automatically using the online interface. Only the GUID transaction number generated by the registration portal must be entered manually in the security module. 

After execution, the applicant receives an online order number from the OSTC system, e.g. OE123456 for online initial application or e.g. OF123456 for an online follow-up application.

Inbound Check of Certificate Request

After you have successfully transferred your files to the ITSG Trust Center either via the upload portal or the OSTC online interface, the registration portal checks in the background whether you have transferred your file with the certificate request to the Trust Center with the corresponding GUID.

The transferred request file that contains the public key of the participant key is compared with the content of the hash code file during the inbound check by the Trust Center. After receiving the request file and the hash code file, the registration portal provides the Trust Center with the complete application data for the final check. If you have logged out of the registration portal or have been automatically logged out, you will need to log in again.

Inbound check

 After a successful check from the registration portal that the certificate request with the corresponding GUID was transmitted to the Trust Center, the registration is automatically taken to the last step 10 and a release letter is sent.

Step 10 Enter a Tagging Code

After submitting the complete certificate application, the applicant receives and must complete the registration process by entering a release code in the registration portal.

The letter sent by the Trust Center to the applicant contains an activation code and the hash code of the key submitted for certification. Once the release letter has been received, the contact person or an authorized representative of the applicant must log on to the registration portal again. First, the hash code of the certification application must be visually checked for compliance with the release letter. You can then enter the activation code to complete the registration.

Enter activation code

 The Trust Center now certifies the public key transmitted by the applicant and also transfers this key to the corresponding public directories of the Trust Center. As a result, the applicant is activated as a participant in electronic data exchange with employers or electronic data exchange with service providers.

You can use the participant number and the order number on the page https://www.itsg- trust.de/all/oav.php  to register for online application tracking and view the status of your certification application.

Transferring Certified Participant Keys and Activation 

The certified public key of the applicant is stored in a certificate file (e.g. B. 12345678.p7c) for the transfer. The contact person is informed by e-mail.

The certificate file is available for download via the online application tracking on the page https://www.itsg-trust.de/all/oav.php . The transfer of the certified key must be triggered manually by the applicant.

Configuring the Key Data and Certificate File in SAP BTP Cockpit

When you configure the communication settings between your business system SAP S4/HANA Cloud Public Edition and the German pension insurance authority's system, you need to enter the key data (such as company number or sender number) as identification number. When configuring the authentication settings, the certificate file should be uploaded.

Communication setting

Authentication Setting

For more information, see the documentation Integration with a Service for Electronic Submission on the SAP Help Portal.

I hope you find this information helpful. If you have any further questions, feel free to leave a comment on this blog post or discover more information in the following documentation:

  • German euBP Files 
  • Managing Communication Settings 
  • Process-Specific Settings

entry.title: Important Update: Tax Reporting Date Change for Canadian Company Codes
entry.content:
✨At SAP, your feedback truly matters—and we take it seriously. Based on your input, we’ve introduced an important change: the Tax Reporting Date will now always default to the Posting Date when creating accounting documents for Canadian company codes.

📊This means that SAP Document and Reporting Compliance (DRC) sales tax reports for Canada will now use the posting date as the tax reporting date.

🔍What’s Changing?

  • ✅The Tax Reporting Date is always suggested as the Posting Date for Canadian company codes, regardless of the T001-XSTDT configuration.
  • 🛠Standard Enhancement Implementation VATDATE_VALUES_DEFAULT_SAP from BAdI Definition VATDATE_RULES has been adjusted.

Depending on your SAP S/4HANA version:

  • 💻SAP S/4HANA & SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Private Edition:
    Please review SAP Note 3678561 – DRC Canada: Corrections to Tax Reporting Date.
    Changes were made in the standard Enhancement Implementation VATDATE_VALUES_DEFAULT_SAP of BAdI VATDATE_VALUES. If you have a custom implementation of this BAdI, changes will not be reflected.

  • ☁️SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud:
    Starting December 14, 2025, your sales tax DRC reports will automatically use the posting date as the tax reporting date.

  • 🆕New Customers:
    The updated logic will apply by default.

📌Example:
If you receive and post a vendor invoice in January 2026 (posting date), but the document date is December 2025, DRC will include the invoice in the January 2026 tax report.

📚Want to Learn More?
For more details about SAP Document and Reporting Compliance for Canada, please visit the SAP Help Portal.

entry.title: Key Apps for GSTR-6 and ISD Management: India
entry.content:
This blog provides a summary of the apps and their functions required to file GSTR-6 in SAP S/4HANA Cloud (formerly known as SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition).

GSTR-6 is the mandatory monthly return for an Input Service Distributor (ISD),  a critical compliance piece for large enterprises with centralized procurement, such as software companies with multiple offices under the same PAN. The ISD mechanism allows the Head Office to receive input service invoices (like consulting or software licenses) centrally and then distribute the associated Input Tax Credit (ITC) to the unit locations where the services are actually consumed.

The SAP S/4HANA system manages this distribution automatically through ISD program known as J1IG_ISDN . It calculates how much of the total ITC each branch should get. This calculation is usually based on a fair measure, like the turnover (sales) of each branch relative to the others and maintained in configuration settings.

SAP generates special internal documents (ISD invoices) that formally transfer the tax credit to each branch. This allows the individual branches to legally reduce their own tax bill by the credit they received.

Here are the apps that assist users in creating ISD invoices and filing GSTR-6 returns:

  1. Re-distribute and Create ISD Invoices
  2. eDocument Cockpit/ Manage Electronic Documents
  3. Resolve Electronic Document Inconsistencies
  4. Run Statuary Reports

              I.                  Re-distribute and Create ISD Invoices:

    This app helps users to create, display and redistribute Input Service Distribution invoices. Users select the filter criteria like Company code, Fiscal Year, ISD Business Place and selection of documents based on posting date. Further, based on the selection, A processing action can be triggered to view the ISD distribution, Change ISD distribution or to Post ISD distribution and create ISD invoices.

     

    App Name/ Launcher Title

    Re-distribute and Create ISD Invoices

    App ID

    J1IG_ISDN

    Business Catalogue

    SAP_FIN_BC_GLO_GSTISD_IN_PC

    Business Catalogue  Description

    Globalization - Input Service Distribution for India

    Business Role

    SAP_BR_PURCHASER_IN

    Business Role Description

    Purchaser for India

     

              II.                  EDOCUMENT Cockpit/ Manage Electronic Documents

    Users can use either eDocument Cockpit app or Manage Electronic Document App to work with electronic documents.

    App Name/ Launcher Title

    Manage Electronic Documents

    App ID

    F4306

    Business Catalogue

    SAP_SD_BC_GLO_EDOC_PC

    Business Catalogue  Description

    Globalization - Electronic Documents

    Business Role

    SAP_BR_BILLING_CLERK

    Business Role Description

    Billing Clerk

     

    App Name/ Launcher Title

    eDocument Cockpit

    App ID

    EDOC_COCKPIT

    Business Catalogue

    SAP_SD_BC_GLO_EDOC_PC

    Business Catalogue  Description

    Globalization - Electronic Documents

    Business Role

    SAP_BR_BILLING_CLERK

    Business Role Description

    Billing Clerk

    eDocument cockpit app allows users to process electronic documents (eDocuments) that are created automatically based on source documents. Users can display eDocuments, submit documents in XML to external systems and monitor the respective status for subsequent actions.

    What are the differences between the Manage Electronic Documents app and eDocument Cockpit app?

              III.                  Resolve Electronic Document Inconsistencies

    This is the app where users can review inconsistencies in the documents for example a document is available in GSTR-6A but missing in Book of accounts or if a document is missing in Tax authority but available in Book of accounts. Users then decide to accept the documents based on available info or may wait for the correction of the records. Only the accepted documents are picked by ISD distribution program. Please note this is the same action you will be navigated to 'Prepare ITC' action mentioned in following  step IV - Run Statuary Reports.

     

    App Name/ Launcher Title

    Resolve Electronic Document Inconsistencies - India

    App ID

    F8406

    Business Catalogue

    SAP_SD_BC_GLO_EDC_IN_PC

    Business Catalogue  Description

    Globalization - Electronic Documents Consistency for India

    SAP_BR_BILLING_CLERK_IN

    Billing Clerk for India

              IV.                  Run Statuary Reports

    This is the main App where GSTR-6 filing steps are performed. There are 5 actions/steps involved as shown below:

     

    App Name/ Launcher Title
